questions.text: Which of the following is transmitted by all the components of blood?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Malaria Malaria infect RBCs by trophozoite and hence malaria can be transmitted by packed Red blood cells only, not by all component of blood

Highyeild:

Blood transfusion related infections Transfusion Transmitted Infections (TTI) HIV HTLV Hepatitis B and C Cytomegalovirus Epstein-Barr virus Human Parvovirus (B19) Prions. Human Herpesvirus 8 Bacterial contamination of blood products. Syphilis. Malaria. Prions.

questions.text: Patient presents with neck swelling. Excision biopsy finding is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tuberculosis Histopathological image form neck swelling shows necrotizing epithelioid cell granulomas with Langhan’s type of giant cell formation is suggestive of Tuberculosis

Highyeild:

MORPHOLOGY Sites of Primary Tuberculosis- Lung, intestine , tonsil and skin (very rare). Lung: It is the commonest site of primary tuberculosis. Ghon lesion: Following inhalation, tubercle bacilli gets deposited in the distal airspaces. Site of deposit: Usually lower part of the upper lobe or upper part of the lower lobe near the pleural surface (subpleural). Ghon focus: About 2–4 weeks after the infection, a circumscribed gray-white area of about 1–1.5 cm develops in the lung known as the Ghon focus→ the center of which undergoes caseous necrosis. Regional lymphadenitis: Tubercle bacilli (free or within macrophages) are carried along the lymphatics to the regional draining nodes → which often show caseous necrosis. Histology Caseating granuloma consists of: Central area of caseous necrosis Surrounded by epithelioid cells (modified macrophages), some of which may fuse to form multinucleate giant cells . The giant cells may be Langhans type (nuclei arranged in horseshoe pattern) or foreign body type (nuclei in the center). The epithelioid cells are surrounded by rim of lymphocytes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B. It will not shows central caseation and Langhans type of giant cell formation Option: C. G ranuloma formation will not be seen Option: D. It will show Reed-Sternberg cells

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker for Gastrointestinal stromal tumors?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NRG-1 75% of all GISTs have oncogenic, gain-of- function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT . While 8% of GISTs have activating mutations in platelet-derived growth factor receptor α (PDGFRA). Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is a subset of wild-type GIST that constitutes approximately 10% of gastric GISTs

Highyeild:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) It arises from the pacemaker of GIT known as interstitial cells of Cajal GIST is the most common mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen The most common location of the GIST is the stomach It is associated with patients having neurofibromatosis-1 75% of all GISTs have oncogenic, gain-of- function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase KIT . While 8% of GISTs have activating mutations in platelet-derived growth factor receptor α (PDGFRA). Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) is a subset of wild-type GIST that constitutes approximately 10% of gastric GISTs GIST frequently shows ulcerated mucosa and histology will show either epithelioid cells, spindle cells, or mixed (both epithelioid cells spindle cells). The most useful diagnostic IHC markers are DOG (detected on GIST) and c-kit (CD 117). CD 34 and SMA also shows positivity Treatment is preferably surgical resection and non-excisable tumors are managed with tyrosine kinase inhibitors called imatinib mesylate or sunitinib

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B and C- These are explained above

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency following a heavy bleed and was transfused with multiple units of blood. Which of the following is not seen as a result of delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: Cola coloured urine in the first 2 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Failure of rise in Hemoglobin level

questions.correct_answer: A. Cola coloured urine in the first 2 hours
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cola coloured urine in the first 2 hours Cola colored urine is not included in the delayed hemolytic reaction, rest of the parameters are seen in delayed hemolytic reaction after blood transfusion

Highyeild:

Delayed hemolytic reactions are caused by antibodies that recognize red cell antigen that the recipient was sensitized to previously through a blood transfusion . There are typically IgG antibodies and are associated with positive coombs test and laboratory features of hemolysis (low haptoglobin, raised bilirubin, elevated LDH)

questions.text: Which of the following does not differentiate between Necrosis and Apoptosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Intact plasma membrane, altered structure specifically in the envelope lipids

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intact cell contents By intact cell content, it will not differentiate necrosis and apoptosis.

Highyeild:

Features Necrosis Apoptosis Cell size Enlarged (swelling) Reduced (shrinkage) Nucleus ● Pyknosis ● karyorrhexis ● karyolysis Fragmentation into nucleosome size fragment Plasma membrane Disrupted Intact; altered structure especially orientation of lipids Cellular contents Enzymatic digestion; may leak out of cells Intact, may be released in apoptotic bodies Adjacent inflammation Frequent No physiological or pathological Usually pathological (cumulation of irreversible injury) Often physiological; means of eliminating unwanted cells may be pathological after some form of cell injury, especially DNA damage

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C and D. Already explained above

questions.text: Given below is the image of a survival analysis curve in patients with organ transplant, which of the following statements are true about the graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Both CD4 and CD8 cells take part in allograft rejection

options.label: B
options.text: Both CD4 and CD8 participate in the protection against allograft rejection

options.label: C
options.text: CD4 cells are not involved in allograft rejection

options.label: D
options.text: CD8 cells have a predominant role in graft rejection

questions.correct_answer: A. Both CD4 and CD8 cells take part in allograft rejection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both CD4 and CD8 cells take part in allograft rejection When anti CD 4 and anti CD 8 given the survival of the organ transplant patient survival is increased

Highyeild:

Here graph depicts that the when anti CD 4 and anti CD 8 given together, the survival of the organ transplant patient survival is increased When only anti CD 4 is given survival times is less (15 days) while When only anti CD 8 is given survival times is less (30 days).

questions.text: In comparison to Ulcerative colitis, Crohn's is associated with:

options.label: A
options.text: Continuous lesions rather than segmented lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Associated with increased risk of developing cancer

options.label: D
options.text: Less likely to present with daily hematochezia

questions.correct_answer: D. Less likely to present with daily hematochezia
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Less likely to present with daily hematochezia Crohn’s disease is less likely associated with daily hematochezia, while the rest others are the features of ulcerative colitis. Feature Crohn's Disease Ulcerative Colitis A. Macroscopic features ● Distribution Segmental with skip areas Q Continuous without skip areas Q ● Location Commonly terminal ileum (most common) and/or ascending colon Commonly rectum sigmoid colon and extending upwards ● Extent Usually involves the entire thickness of the affected segment of bowel wall Usually superficial, confined to mucosal layers ● Ulcers Serpiginous ulcers, that develop into deep fissures Q Superficial mucosal ulcers without fissures ● Pseudopolyps Rarely seen Commonly present Q ● Fibrosis Common Rare ● Shortening Due to fibrosis Due to contraction of muscularis B. Microscopic features ● Depth of inflammation Typically transmural Q Mucosal Q and Submucosal ● Type of inflammation Non-caseating granulomas Q and infiltrate of mononuclear cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells and macrophage Crypt abscess and non-specific acute and chronic inflammatory cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells neutrophils, eosinophils, mast cells) ● Mucosa Patchy ulceration Hemorrhagic mucosa with ulceration ● Submucosa Widened due to edema and lymphoid aggregates Normal or reduced in width ● Muscularis Infiltrated by inflammatory cells Usually spared, except in cases of Toxic Megacolon Q ● Fibrosis Present Usually absent C. Complications ● Fistula formation Internal and external fistulae in 10% case Extremely rare Q ● Malignant changes Less common but present May occur in disease of more than 10 years duration (more common Q ) ● Fibrous strictures common Q Never Q ● Toxic megacolon - Risk present Q ● Features ● Hose pipe appearance Q ● Cobble-stone appearance Q ● Halo sign on CT Q ● String sign of cantor Q ● Raspberry/rosethorn appearance Q ● Garden hose appearance Q ● Pseudopolyps Q ● Pipestem colon (Ahaustral) Q

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Kawasaki disease?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Purulent conjunctivitis Kawasaki disease is associated with non purulent conjunctivitis , rest ( strawberry tongue, rash and cervical lymphadenopathy) are the features of Kawasaki disease

Highyeild:

Kawasaki's Disease (Infantile Polyarteritis, Mucocutaneous Lymph Node Syndrome) Acute febrile Q , usually self-limited illness of infancy and childhood Q (80% patients are ≤ 4 years) It is associated with an arteritis affecting large to medium- sized, and even small vessels Kawasaki's disease (CREAM) C-Conjunctivitis (non-exudative); non purulent conjunctivitis R-Rash (Polymorphous non-vesicular) E-Edema (or erythema of hands or feet) A-Adenopathy (cervical, often unilateral and non-suppurative) M-Mucosal involvement (erythema or fissures or crusting at times referred as strawberry tongue Q ) F-Fever (most important constitutional symptom Q ) Diagnostic criteria: Anti-endothelial cell antibodies Q . Leading cause of acquired heart disease Q in children. Coronary artery involvement Q aneurysms that rupture or thrombose → Acute Myocardial Infarction Q

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B, C and D: Already explained above

questions.text: Calcification in histopathology image. Which of the following marked areas show calcification?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A Among the marked structure basophilic (blue) granular appearances

Highyeild:

Calcification Gross : Appear as fine, white granules or clumps , feels gritty and sand-like. Microscopy: Basophilic, amorphous granular , clumped appearance. Two types Features Dystrophic Metastatic Seen in Dead tissues Q , damaged & aging tissues Living tissues Serum Calcium Normal Q Elevated Sites Seen in cell injury and necrosis Q Mainly affects gastric mucosa Q , kidneys Q , lungs Q , systemic arteries Q & pulmonary veins Q . Effect Organ dysfunction Usually no clinical dysfunction, but massive involvement may cause organ damage Etiology "R-A-T-T" R-Rheumatic heart ds (Cardiac valves) A-Atheromatous plaque T-Tubercular lymph node T-Tumors (MP-PG) ● Meningioma, Mesothelioma ● Papillary carcinoma of thyroid, Ovary (serous carcinoma) ● Prolactinoma ● Glucagonoma Examples of Dystrophic Calcification ● Psammoma bodies Q ● Asbestos bodies Q ● Mönckeberg's sclerosis Q ● PRDR (Postgraduate Reads Dr.) ● Hyperparathyroidism- ○ Parathyroid tumors ○ Ectopic PTHRP from malignant tumors ● Resorption of bone tissue- ○ Multiple myeloma Q ○ Diffuse skeletal metastasis ○ Accelerated bone turnover-Pagets' disease ○ Immobilization ● Vitamin D-related disorders ○ Vitamin D intoxication, ○ Sarcoidosis (Macrophages activate vit D precursor) ○ Idiopathic hypercalcemia of infancy (Williams syndrome) Q ● Renal failure-Due to secondary hyperparathyroidism ● Others: Milk alkali syndrome, Aluminum intoxication ● Vitamin A toxicity

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding myelodysplastic syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Treatment induced MDS is not dependent on age

questions.correct_answer: A. More commonly seen in females
questions.explanation:
Solution:

More commonly seen in females Myelodysplastic Syndromes (MDS) are a heterogeneous group of acquired clonal stem cell disorders affecting stem cells MDS is characterized by: Progressive cytopenias Dysplasia in one or more cell lines Ineffective hematopoiesis Risk of development of AML. Classification Idiopathic or primary MDS Secondary/therapy -related MDS (t-MDS):Complication of previous cytotoxic drug or radiation therapy. WHO classification MDS with single lineage dysplasia MDS with ring sideroblasts MDS with ring sideroblasts and single lineage dysplasia MDS with ring sideroblasts and multilineage dysplasia MDS with multilineage dysplasia MDS with excess blasts MDS with isolated del(5q) MDS, unclassifiable Clinical features Elderly above 60 years Slightly more c ommon in males Symptoms are due to cytopenias About 10%–40% of MDS patients progress to AML Laboratory findings Peripheral smear: Cytopenias in the peripheral blood RBCs: Mild to moderate degree of macrocytic or dimorphic anemia . WBCs: Normal or low total leukocyte count. Platelets: Variable thrombocytopenia , large hypogranular or giant platelet Bone marrow findings Dysplasia of all nonlymphoid lineages (erythroid, granulocytic, monocytic and megakaryocytic) associated with cytopenias. Cellularity: Hypercellular. Erythropoiesis: Dysplastic changes in erythroid precursors with megaloblastoid change and presence of ringed sideroblasts in iron stain. Myelopoiesis: Hyperplasia with dysgranulopoiesis. Megakaryopoiesis: Dysmegakaryopoiesis—pawn ball megakaryocytes.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B, C and D. Already explained above

questions.text: Aneurysm due to excessive degradation of connective tissue is seen in which of these disorders?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ehlers Danlos syndrome Aneur ysm due to excessive degradation occurs in Ehlers Danlos syndrome while due to defect is structural glycoprotein is due to Marfan syndrome

Highyeild:

Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes (EDSs) EDSs comprise a clinically and genetically heterogeneous group of disorders that result from some mutations in genes that encode collagen, enzymes that modify collagen, and less commonly other proteins present in the extracellular matrix Classification of Ehler Danlos syndrome EDS Type Clinical Findings Inheritance Gene Defects Classic (I/II) Skin and joint hypermobility, atrophic scars, easy bruising Autosomal dominant COLSAI, COLSA2 Hypermobility (III) Joint hypermobility, pain, dislocations Autosomal dominant Unknown Vascular (IV) Thin skin, arterial or uterine rupture, bruising, small joint hyperextensibility Autosomal dominant COL3AI Kyphoscoliosis (VI) Hypotonia, joint laxity, congenital scoliosis, ocular fragility Autosomal recessive Lysyl hydroxylase Arthrochalasia (Vila, VIIb) Severe joint hypermobility, skin changes (mild), scoliosis, bruising Autosomal dominant COLIAI, COLIA2 Dermatosparaxis (VIIc) Severe skin fragility, cutis laxa, bruising Autosomal recessive Procollagen N-peptidase

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Here, structu ral protein defects occurs, not degradation Option: C. Aneurysm does not occurs Option: D. Atherosclerosis as a chronic inflammatory and healing response of the arterial wall to endothelial injury . Lesion progression occurs through interaction of modified lipoproteins, macrophages, and T lymphocytes with ECs and SMCs of the arterial wall

questions.text: Identify the given histopathological image of lung carcinoma:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Adenocarcinoma Presence of glands lined by columnar epithelial cells and invading into the underlying structure is suggestive of adenocarcinoma

Highyeild:

Histological variant of lung carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Adenocarcinoma Small cell cancer or oat cancer Large cell cancer MC type of lung cancer in smokers Q . Overall MC type of cancer Q . Associated with smoking MC type in males Q . MC type in non-smokers and females Q . Commoner in smokers Q . Usually central in location (arise from the segmental bronchi) Usually peripheral in location (arise from terminal bronchiole) Central in location Peripheral in location. Shows highest frequency of p53 mutation Q . Associated with K-ras mutation Q . Immunohistochemistry shows high expression of Bcl-2 gene Q in majority of tumors. Intercellular bridges or junction is very specific. Histologically, the tumor has presence of keratinization Q . Glandular pattern of growth of the tumor is seen. Cells are positive for mucin, thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1) Q and Napsin-A (sensitive as well as specific marker Cells have scanty cytoplasm, small nucleoli, granular chromatin (salt and pepper pattern Q ). Azzopardi effect (Basophilic staining of vascular walls) is frequently present. Electron microscopy shows presence of neurosecretory granules chromogranin, synaptophysis and leu-7 Q . Cells have large nuclei, prominent nucleoli and a moderate amount of cyto- plasm. Highest association with cavitation Has the best prognosis Has best response to chemo- therapy and radiotherapy. Has the worst prognosis Q . Most aggressive lung cancer Q . Hypercalcemia Q due to PTHrP is the MC paraneoplastic syndrome. Associated with maximum para- neoplastic syndrome Q (particularly SIADH and Cushing syndrome). Has gynecomastia as paraneoplastic syndrome Q .

questions.text: Which of the following about Hodgkin's lymphoma is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Waldeyer's ring is the most common site to be involved

options.label: B
options.text: RS cells are immunopositive for CD30 and PAX5

options.label: C
options.text: RS Cells are of B cell origin

options.label: D
options.text: Nodular sclerosis is the most commonly presents as a mediastinal mass

questions.correct_answer: A. Waldeyer's ring is the most common site to be involved
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Waldeyer's ring is the most common site to be involved Reed-Sternberg cells are of B cell origin and show immunopositivity for PAX 5, CD 15 and CD 30. Nodular sclerosis variants of Hodgkin’s lymphoma have high propensity to involve cervical and mediastinal lymph nodes. These are the correct statements.

Highyeild:

Reed- Sternberg cell Diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells are large cells with multiple nuclei or a single nucleus with multiple nuclear lobes, each with a large inclusion-like nucleolus The Reed-Sternberg cells in the nodular sclerosis variant and other classic Hodgkin lymphoma shows positivity for PAX5 (a B-cell transcription factor), CD15, and CD30 . Reed-Sternberg cell is B cell in origin The nodular sclerosis has a propensity to involve the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes of adolescents or young adults Waldeyer’s ring is not the most common site to be involved by the Hodgkin’s lymphoma Description of different Subtypes of Hodgkin Lymphoma Subtype Morphology Immunophenotype Association with EBV Typical Clinical Features Nodular sclerosis Lacunar cells (clear space around nucleus) a Fibrous strands & plasma cells a CD15+, CD30+; usually EBV- MC in World a ; M=F; usually stage I or II; frequent mediastinal involvement; Good prognosis a Mixed cellularity Mononuclear cells CD15+, CD30+; 70% EBV+ MC in India a , stage III or IV; M > F; biphasic incidence; Good prognosis a Lymphocyte rich Mononuclear cells CD15+, CD30+; 40% EBV+ Uncommon; M > F, Good prognosis a Lymphocyte depletion Reticular variant: CD15+, CD30+; 90% EBV+ (Maximum) a Uncommon; M>F; HIV infected a Poorest Prognosis a Lymphocyte predominance Lymphocytic & Histiocytic (popcorn cell) a CD20+, CD15-, C30-; EBV- Uncommon; young males with cervical or axillary L. nodes, Best Prognosis a

questions.text: Which of the following is the nuclear neuroendocrine immunohistochemical marker?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

INSM1 INSM 1 is nuclear marker of neuroendocrine differentiation with equivalent or better sensitivity and specificity compared to synaptophysin, chromogranin and CD56

Highyeild:

Insulinoma associated protein 1 (INSM 1) INSM 1 is nuclear marker of neuroendocrine differentiation with equivalent or better sensitivity and specificity compared to synaptophysin, chromogranin and CD56 Cytoplasmic Markers of neuroendocrine differentiation are synaptophysin, chromogranin, NSE and CD56

questions.text: A patient was brought to emergency following a severe hemorrhage and was not able to get the matching blood type. Which blood group can be used for immediate transfusion? A positive AB negative O positive O negative Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3 and 4 only O negative is considered as a universal donor and can be given in any emergency condition, here in option O positive and O negative is given together

Highyeild:

O negative is considered as a universal donor and can be given in any emergency condition, here in option O positive and O negative is given together O Positive blood should not be transfused in female in any emergency to prevent further allo-immunization The ABO and Rh Blood Group Systems The ABO and Rh Blood Group Systems Properties ABO system Rh system Blood groups 4 main blood groups: A, B, AB and O a Rh positive and negative Genetic loci On chromosome 9 a On chromosome 1 a Antigens and Antibodies Group Antigen Antibody ● C, c, D, E, e Antigens a ● 'd' indicates the absence of D a ● Anti D Antibody: Most important a O H Anti-A and Anti-B a A A Anti-B a B B Anti-A a AB A and B None a Antigens also seen on/in Endothelial and epithelial cells a Plasma, saliva, semen (not in CSF) a No other cells a Type of Ab IgM a ; naturally occurring a antibodies IgG a ; Do not occur naturally Clinical importance ● Anti-A and anti-B Ab can cause severe intravascular hemolysis after incompatible transfusion a . ● ABO- matching is required before transplantation a of solid organs Rh-ve individuals make anti-D Ab if: ● Transfused with Rh +ve blood a or, ● Rh-ve pregnant women, is exposed to Rh +ve fetal RBCs a that have crossed the placenta.

questions.text: Match the blood component with shelf life: Select the correct option from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-3, B- 4, C- 2, D- 1 RBCs with CPD-A solution can be stored for 42 days, single donor platelets with solution can be stored for 5 day, cryoprecipitate can be stored for 1 year and granulocytes can be stored for 1 day

Highyeild:

Shelf life and storage of different blood components Blood component Storage temperature Shelf life Indications Whole blood 2-6°C 42 days ● Acute blood loss ● Exchange transfusion Packed red cells 2-6°C 42 days ● Severe anemia ● Exchange transfusion Platelets 20-24°C 5 days (platelet agitator) ● Thrombocytopenia Cryoprecipitate -24°C 1 year ● Hemophilia A ● vW disease ● Factor 13 deficiency ● Fibrinogen deficiency Fresh frozen plasma -24°C 1 year ● DIC ● Hemophilia B ● Liver disease
